entry.title: What is correct set up of Rebate sales condition types REA1 & RES1 in relevant pricing procedures ?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

Can someone please clarify on usage of S4 HANA sales rebate condition types REA1 and RES1 in the pricing procedures RVAA01 and A10005 ?

A10005 - Condition contract pricing procedure for calculation of settlement amount.)

entry.title: Extend C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt with custom fields in Fiori app Manage Purchase Requisitions (F2229)
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We want to extend Account Assignment table in Purchase Requisition Item with a few custom fields (columns) that are added using Append Structure in table EBKN. From our understanding, we need to extend the CDS view C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt. 

This CDS view seems to have a chain of CDS selection before finally getting the data from table EBKN, i.e. C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt -> T_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt -> I_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt -> I_PurReqnAcctAssgmt -> I_PurReqnAcctAssgmtBasic -> EBKN.

After checking some documentation, we found another CDS view E_Purreqnacctassgmt, which we thought could be used, but extending it doesn't help us in accessing those custom fields in C_PurchaseReqnAcctAssgmt or directly in the Fiori app.

Could someone suggest which CDS views we should extend to get these columns (custom fields) in the Fiori app, or is there a better way?

We tried checking first in Custom Fields and Logic app for a relevant Business Context for PR Account Assignment, but couldn't find anything appropriate. We still would like to keep our development as clean-core as possible.

Here are some of the ways customers and partners are driving transformation with SAP BTP.

  • Global agri-business Olam Agri ‚Äî with S$33.2 billion in annual revenue ‚Äî transformed its finance operations with SAP BTP.
  • In just nine months, Olam Agri migrated from ECC to RISE with SAP on AWS, covering 35 countries and 90 entities.
  • Using SAP Integration Suite, the company established real-time bank connectivity and freed S$250 million in treasury cash.

Mamee: Building Agility and Modernizing Operations

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Extensibility: Extensibility Templates, Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

SAP BTP Developer‚Äôs Guide, OData V4 Tutorial, About the OData API Reference Guide (V4)

To summarise, the public cloud edition Clean-Core approach restricts you from downloading or modifying the source code of standard Fiori apps. This ensures that the content delivered by SAP stay locked and thereby ensuring upgrade safety and lifecycle consistency.

What SAP offers you is to:

  • Inspect the Fiori apps technical details through the ‚ÄúAbout App‚Äù
  • Re-use the apps OData/API service on BTP, and
  • Extend its functionality by using its Clean Core extensibility options.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Wrong material valuation - correction?
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Finance 

Dear community, 

we noticed a problem in our material ledger (material valuation). Couple of our products were correctly costed (Costing 2 tab in product master data) but the price was not correctly updated in Accounting 1 tab in some ledgers/currencies. We also noticed that the costing lot size was 100, price unit at the costing 2 tab was 100, but in the accounting tab it was 100 only under 2L ledger and currency 10 (all other ledgers and currencies had price unit 1) => this should not cause the issue because the system is recalculating it but for some reason it didn't. 

(amounts are just illustrative). 
A product was costed 10,000 HUF / 24.57 EUR per 100 pieces (Costing 2 tab). This amount was also correct in our 2L ledger and currency 10 in the accounting 1 tab. 
Other currencies under 2L (30 + functional currency) and all under 0L (10,30,FC) were determined incorrectly:  10,000 HUF / 24.57 EUR per 1piece.  (2,457 per 100 pieces)

This caused wrong booking when a production order was confirmed. Now we have:

2L (currency 10): 1,000 pieces with total value of 100,000 HUF (correct)
0L (currency 10): 1,000 pieces with total value of 10,000,000 HUF (wrong)
2L (currency 30,FC): 1,000 pieces with total value of 24,570 EUR (wrong)
0L (currency 30,FC): 1,000 pieces with total value of 24,570 EUR (wrong)

We ran a new costing which corrected the Accounting 1 tab so we believe that the future posting should be ok. But we don't know how to correct the wrong balance sheet amounts (the costing itself didn't post revaluation because the costing 2 tab didn't change). 

We found couple of applications like Adjust Inventory Balance Sheet Accounts - Delta Posting but we don't know if it solves the problem. 

Thank you!
Pavel

entry.title: AWS Route 53 setup for multiple Hana Cloud instances with Private Link
entry.content:
So, I'm planning  on spinning up multiple hana cloud instances, and I want to use AWS private link.

Getting one instance in AWS us-east to work was easy; just configure Route 53 to point

*.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com -> the vpc endpoint

But let's say I've got another instance I want to connect to, within the same VPC.... should be easy? Just reconfigure Route 53 to do:
<uuid>.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com -> the vpc endpoint

Well, that does not work!

I discovered that hana cloud actually "redirects" to an internal hostname, upon connection. The hostname is in a form that's basically impossible to define in route53 as it requires a 5-digit unknown suffix (and route53 can't do wildcards in a partial subdomain). Here's the spec: https://me.sap.com/notes/3325646

The note does mention an unsupported option that would prevent the redirect, which would then make it easy to map things in route 53. But, it advises against doing that...

Seems to me like unless the service endpoint id is the same for every hana instance in us-east-1,  I don't see how it's possible to use private link when having multiple instances.

I did try setting up a custom domain, but getting TLS errors when connecting using that. This could work, I just don't know how to set that up correctly.

I know there must be a way, so am wondering, has anybody figured this out?

entry.title: Re: Manage Supplier Quotation App Always Creates PO with...
entry.content:
Good day @Vinith 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Supplier Quotations, Sourcing and Procurement

Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2308

Service Order (A2X)

To summarise, in public cloud, that behaviour is controlled by the public cloud scope and you cannot change or influence it though configuration.

That happens because of a few reasons:

  1. The procurement of Direct Materials always calls the standard PO type NB. That logic is part of the SAP standard process integration between Supplier Quotation and Purchase Order object.
  2. In Public Cloud, custom document type determination is not released.

Even though you can create custom document types in ‚ÄúDefine Document Types for Purchase Orders‚Äù configuration, they are usable only when you create Pos manually in Manage Purchase Orders and not during automated follow-on creation from other apps.

The best practice is to either:

1. Stick with the Clean Core approach of manual creation with custom type:

Open Manage Purchase Orders --> Create a new Po with your custom document type --> Reference the supplier quotation under the Source of Supply section.

2. Optionally, use side-by-side to build BTP automation that reads the awarded quotation and calls the Public API Purchase Order ‚Äì Create From Quotation endpoint. You can pass the custom document type (ZNB) in the payload.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Not able to access https://connectsupport.ariba.com/
entry.content:
Regarding to your issue, please refer to KBA 3121688 - S-user ID authorizations for Designated Support Contact (DSC) access or Basic access - SAP Ariba Connect

The Ariba installation for your company account is 90971866, the two S-users you provided are missing authorizations on this installation.

Authorizations needed for Basic access:

  • Display Cloud Data - set at the Ariba installation number level

Authorizations needed for Designated Support Contact (DSC) access:

  • Display Cloud Data - set at the Ariba installation number level
  • Report Technical Problem - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level
  • Close Cases - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level
  • Send Cases to SAP - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level
  • Display Cases - set at Customer Number level or Ariba installation number level

For data security, our SAP always recommend customer to manage S-users/authorizations by themselves. 

Thus please contact below Ariba cloud admin to help assign authorizations these two S-users.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM - Business Service Management - Integration with third-party ITSM Solutions (Part 1)
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

This blog post is part of a small series of posts intended to provide details about SAP Cloud ALM - Business Service Management (BSM) use case. The goal of this blog post is to highlight how BSM use case can support SAP customers during daily operations of SAP cloud landscapes. Also, to provide details how to perform integration of Events offered by BSM use case with third-party ITSM solutions.

The content of the this blog post is following:

Part 1:  Business Service Management - OverviewPart 2: Business Service Management - Event Integration with Third-Party systems
  • Motivation
  • Status Events (Event Types) and Details
  • Integration Scenarios 
  • Defining Business Services
  • External API Management - Event Situations (Status Events)
  • External API Management - How to define Field Mapping
  • External API Management - Webhooks and Subscriptions
  • External API Management - Testing and Troubleshooting

Business Service Management (BSM) - Overview

Motivation:

In SAP Cloud ALM, the Business Service Management use case offers a central location for customers to access information about the 'Status Events' of their SAP Cloud Services. SAP cloud customers can find communication updates like Planned Maintenance, Disruptions, Degradations and other communication notices about their SAP cloud services.

SAP Cloud ALM Business Service Management provides a central IT Calendar where customer can get visibility about SAP Cloud Services and Technical System statuses. Customers can understand whether Cloud Service\System is operational, whether there is any Disruption or Degradation affecting services or when Planned Maintenances are scheduled. Also, t he IT Calendar offered by BSM provides visibility about past and upcoming 'Status Events'.

The source of information for Cloud ALM Business Service Management is the SAP Cloud Availability Center.  SAP Cloud ALM resuses this information within CALM to enhance Operations use cases, but also helps customers to handle these notifications in a more efficient way. For example, by performing integration with third-party ITSM solutions to support SLA tracking or trigger contingency plans in case of Disruptions/Degradations. In addition, Business Service Management in SAP Cloud ALM also provides capabiltites like capabilities such as standard Service Level Reports with possiblity to use custom service level objectives.

SAP Cloud Availability Center offers these 'Status Events' notifications for certain 'Supported Products' . These products are also supported within SAP Cloud ALM..  There are different 'Status Events' types offered (Planned Maintenance, Disruptions, Degradations, and Important Communications), each of these 'Status Events' types has its own lifecycle of communications.
The picture below indicates which type of communication SAP sends to customer depending of the 'Status Event' type:

Integration Scenarios:

SAP customers can leverage Business Service Management to achieve the following integration scenarios with third-party ITSM tools to support daily operations:

  • Planned maintenance events: automatically create change records, schedule windows, and send stakeholder communications aligned to SLAs.
  • Unplanned outages or service disruptions: auto-create incidents, trigger major-incident workflows, and accelerate triage using impact mapping to business services in the CMDB.
  • Performance degradation or partial functional impact: generate alerts, prioritize based on business criticality, and route to the right resolver groups.

The focus of this series of blog posts is to help customers implement the integration of Cloud ALM BSM Events with third-party ITSM solutions for scenarios like the ones mentioned above.

For further information about Business Service Management, check following materials:

  • Cloud ALM Expert Portal - Business Service Management
  • Business Service Management - Overview Presentation
Defining Business Services

The first activity to be performed when starting to leverage Cloud ALM Business Service Management use case is to define the so-called Business Services within the application.  It is mandatory to define one (or more) Business Services in SAP Cloud ALM before configuring 'Notifications' or 'Third-Party Integration' for the 'Status Events' forCloud Services\Systems. 
Next steps show how to define Business Services in SAP Cloud ALM BSM use case:

What are Business Services? 

Initially, let's understand what exactly is a Business Service at Cloud ALM Business Service Management (BSM) use case. The Business Service is basically a container for Cloud Services and Systems which are grouped due to a certain relationship (business or technical functionalities), for example:

  • SAP Production Landscape: A group containing all 'Production' Cloud Services and Systems regardless of their type.
  • SAP non-Production Landscape: A group containing all 'nonProduction' (Sandbox, Development and Quality roles) Cloud Services and Systems regardless of their type.
  • Lead to Cash: A group containing only Cloud Services and Systems relevant to run 'Lead to Cash' process
  • Hire to Retire: A group containing only Cloud Services and Systems relevant to run 'Hire to Retire' process
  • etc.

The Business Services are freely defined by end users to represent groups according to their needs. The Business Services are simple structures, with a name, an additional description, and the relationship to multiple cloud services or technical systems which belonging to the group.

How to define a Business Service in Cloud ALM BSM?

The steps to define a Business Service are quite simple:

1) Access Cloud ALM Business Service Management configuration area:
Access Cloud ALM Launchpad ‚Üí Cloud ALM for Operations ‚Üí Click Business Service Management tile
At he top-right corner, use the ‚ÄòConfiguration‚Äô icons to open configuration pop-up:

Once we have pop-up 'Configuration for Business Services', one can simply quick on 'Add' to create new Business Service.

At 'Basic Information', the first action while creating a new Business Service is to provide a name and a description. Name and Description are freely defined by the end user according to organizational needs.

Then at 'Services / Systems' tab, we select which are the Cloud Services and Systems that will be part of the Business Service. Use the relevant option to add a Cloud Service or Technical System:

NOTE 1: The Cloud Services and Technical Systems available to be added as part of a Business Services are Services\Systems which are registered in the Cloud ALM Landscape Management. SAP Cloud Services and ECS\Rise systems are automatically discovered. 
In case systems are located in a customer managed private landscape, then it is required to register system to Cloud ALM Landscape Management first. 
NOTE 2: Cloud ALM Business Service Management only provides 'Status Events' communications to Services\Systems hosted by  SAP (Cloud Services and ECS\Rise Technical Systems). Customer can still use Business Service Management as central IT Calendar to manage Status Events, but it is customer responsibility to define the events in the IT Calendar accordingly (Planned Maintenance, Disruptions, etc.). 

At tab 'Service Level Objective' (SLO), customers can maintain their own SLOs settings to be tracked by Cloud ALM. Service Level reports are available in Cloud ALM to track SLAs for the Services\Systems part of the Business Service:

In the last tab 'Event Actions' is where the main configuration is performedfor the Business Service. In this tab we can decide actions to be triggered for the available Event Types.
The Cloud ALM Business Service Management offers different type of 'Events' depending on the communication that has to be sent to customer:

  • Disruption: Service is not available due to unplanned disruptive events
  • Degradation: Service usage is limited, for example due to performance problems
  • Maintenance: Service is not available during a defined time interval due to planned and previously announced maintenance activities.
  • Communication: SAP informs about required actions on customer side or planned changes for SAP managed cloud service via customer communication events

For each of these 'Status Events' types, it is possible to trigger Cloud ALM actions for the different lifecycle communcation of the 'Status Event'. As seen before, following communications are avaiable for each 'Status Event' type:

The following actions can be triggered for the avaialble communications:

  • Send Email Notification: Send email notification to relevant users
  • Send Chat Notification: Send notification in a chat channel (e.g., MS Teams)
  • Create Ticket: Create incident in ITSM solution (option that is the focus of this blog series)
  • Start Operation Flow: Trigger an automated task in SAP Build Process Automation / SAP Workflow / Automation Pilot (or third-party solution)

For example: One would like to be notified for the 'Planned Maitenance - Status Events' communications when it gets 'Anounced', also get a 'Remider' and finally gets 'Completed'.
To fulfill this requrement, it is possible to configure the ''Planned Maitenance - Status Event' accordingly to notify end-users with such communications only. The steps below how to achieve this for 'Email Notifications':

Using very similar configuration steps, it is possible to send such communications to the corporate ITSM solution to establish a formal process to trigger follow up activities, e.g. Trigger Contigency Plan/Actions when critical system is not avaiable due to an unplanned 'Disruption' or prepare Business Teams for planned downtime when there is a 'Planned Maintenance' scheduled. 

To perform the integration of Business Service Management with corporate ITSM solution, firstly it is required to establish the technical integration between Cloud ALM and the Corporate ITSM solution. This will be covered in detail in the Part 2 of this blog series.

Best Practices summary for Cloud ALM Business Service Management

The recommended adoption steps for customers are following:

  1. Understand what SAP Cloud Services and Technical Systems (ECS\Rise) are supported by SAP Cloud Availability Center and Cloud ALM Business Service Management
  2. Plan which Business Services should be defined in Cloud ALM Business Service Management to represent SAP landscape
  3. Define which Status Events communications will be leveraged to manage systems
  4. Plan required action plan/process for each Status Events commuication type (Disruption, Planned Maintenance, etc.) whether Email Notification will be used and/or Intgration with Third-Party system is necessary.

I hope this introduction to Cloud ALM Business Service Management use case provides helpful details about the motivation of this feature in SAP Cloud ALM and how customers can benefit from it. In the next blog post we will explore in detail how to perform the integration of this use case with corporate ITSM solution.

  • SAP Cloud ALM - Business Service Management - Integration with third-party ITSM Solutions (Part 2)

Kind Regards,
Allam Drebes

entry.title: Re: Interdependencies between date fields in SAPapps ‚ÄúMan...
entry.content:
Good day @Shubham120798 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Delivery and Transportation Scheduling, Sales Order Processing & Manage Sales Orders

Yes, your observations are correct. I agree that the interaction between date fields can indeed cause confusion or even delivery blocks if your master data and configuration are not aligned.

To summarise, when Planned Delivery Time in MM is unrealistically high, the systems‚Äô backward scheduling pushes the Material Availability Date far into the future. During delivery creation, the system checks ATP: if there is not stock by that date, delivery creation is blocked because no quantity is confirmed.

To better support your process, I suggest you consider the following Best Practices:

  • Run the Check Material Availability in Manage Sales Orders to simulate date logic and see which field drives the schedule.
  • Then Use Display Material √† MRP 2 tab to check the PDT values.
  • Use the Analyse Delivery Schedule or Material Availability Overview to see how each date was derived.
  • Avoid manual overwriting of dates. Rather let scheduling calculate automatically once master data is correct.

Optionally, you can achieve improvements with the Clean-Core by:

  • Activating Situation Handling, which will alert your users when PDT or transportation times cause scheduling delays.
  • Ensure you periodically review and cleanse master data through ‚ÄúData Quality Evaluation for Materials‚Äù app if you have enabled it.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Project Financial Booklet
entry.content:
Good day @jantoniomoyano3 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Investment Projects (1NT), Project Budget Report & Budget Availability Control for Projects

To summarise, the Project Financial Booklet app is not suitable for investment projects. That app supports Professional Services and Customer/Expense projects with revenue components but does not handle capital-investment projects settled to Assets Under Construction (AUC).

For investments projects, use the Project Budget Report, Project Cost Report, and Monitor Budget Consumption to ensure accurate budget tracking and viability control.

Optionally enhance with SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards for consolidated financial visibility.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: RITA for B2C customer in S4HANA public cloud
entry.content:
Good day @edwinvk 

Thank you for your question.

In Public Cloud, RITA and VAT reporting depend on tax registration and country activation in configuration, not necessarily on the presence of a company code or plant in that country.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Global Tax Management with SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2202, VAT Reporting,

https://help.sap.com/doc/fa181291cb2f488aa123d516cce53db0/2025.0/en-US/CC_Administration_and_Operation_Guide.pdf

https://help.sap.com/doc/df6888467ece41fdaaa5958218d71979/1.0.02/en-US/637b91b5b582434e81af25be9642f95f.pdf

To summarise, yes, you can activate a foreign country RITA without creating a company or plant. You only need to activate the country for tax, maintain VAT registration numbers, and let tax determination handle the correct VAT automatically.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Deploying GRC for SAP HANA 2026 requires a focus on both technical and strategic readiness.
entry.content:
To successfully deploy SAP GRC for HANA 2026, you'll need to prepare across several technical and functional areas. Here's a concise and meaningful checklist to guide your initial setup:

 Initial Prerequisites for SAP GRC on HANA 2026

  1. System Compatibility
  • Ensure SAP S/4HANA version supports GRC 2026
  • Confirm SAP NetWeaver and HANA DB versions meet minimum requirements
  1. Infrastructure Readiness
  • Validate hardware sizing (CPU, memory, storage)
  • Confirm supported OS (typically Linux for HANA)
  1. Licensing & Roles
  • Acquire licenses for GRC modules: Access Control, Process Control, Risk Management
  • Define and assign user roles with appropriate authorizations
  1. Connectivity & Integration
  • Set up RFC destinations (SM59)
  • Configure connectors via SPRO (local, plug-in, callback)
  1. Installation & Configuration
  • Download installation media from SAP Software Center
  • Activate required business functions
  • Configure workflows, notifications, and organizational structures
  1. Governance & Planning
  • Align GRC controls with internal policies and external regulations
  • Prepare training and change management plans
  • Document system landscape and integration points

Would you like help customizing this checklist for your organization or drafting a deployment roadmap?

give me with full note

Certainly! Here's a full, detailed note on the initial prerequisites and checklist for deploying SAP GRC for SAP HANA 2026, suitable for documentation, training, or sharing with your team:

Initial Prerequisites & Checklist for Deploying SAP GRC on SAP HANA 2026

Deploying SAP Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) for HANA 2026 is a strategic initiative that requires careful planning across infrastructure, system compatibility, licensing, and integration. Below is a comprehensive checklist to guide your deployment preparation.

  1. System Compatibility & Infrastructure
  • SAP S/4HANA Version: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system is compatible with GRC for HANA 2026. This version consolidates Access Control, Process Control, and Risk Management modules.
  • SAP NetWeaver Stack: Verify the NetWeaver version meets the minimum requirements for GRC 2026.
  • SAP HANA Database: Confirm the HANA DB version is supported and properly sized for GRC workloads.
  • Operating System: Typically Linux; ensure OS is certified for SAP HANA and GRC.
  • Hardware Sizing:
    • CPU, memory, and disk space should be planned based on expected GRC usage.
    • Use SAP Quick Sizer or consult SAP sizing guidelines.
  1. 2. Licensing & User Roles
  • GRC Module Licenses:
    • Access Control
    • Process Control
    • Risk Management
  • User Role Definitions:
    • GRC Administrator
    • Business Process Owner
    • Risk Manager
    • Auditor
  • Authorization Setup:
    • Assign appropriate roles and authorizations using SAP roles and profiles.
    • Ensure segregation of duties (SoD) principles are applied.
  1. 3. Integration & Connectivity
  • RFC Destinations:
    • Configure RFC connections using transaction SM59.
    • Validate connectivity between GRC and target systems (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, ECC).
  • Connector Configuration:
    • Use SPRO to navigate to: Governance, Risk, and Compliance ‚Üí Integration Framework ‚Üí Create Connectors
    • Define connector types:
      • Local Connector
      • Plug-in Connector
      • Callback Connector
  • System Landscape Documentation:
    • List all systems involved in GRC integration.
    • Include system IDs, roles, and connection types.
  1. Installation & Configuration
  • Installation Media:
    • Download GRC 2026 packages from SAP Software Center.
    • Validate checksum and version before installation.
  • Basic Configuration Tasks:
    • Activate required business functions via SFW5.
    • Set up organizational structures (e.g., company codes, business units).
    • Configure workflows, notifications, and approval processes.
  • Transport Management:
    • Prepare transport requests for configuration and custom developments.
    • Use CTS+ if deploying across multiple landscapes.
  1. Data Migration & Upgrade Planning
  • Upgrade Path:
    • If migrating from GRC 12.0, plan for data migration and compatibility checks.
  • Legacy Data Validation:
    • Clean up obsolete roles, rules, and workflows.
    • Map legacy controls to new GRC structures.
  • Testing Strategy:
    • Unit testing, integration testing, and user acceptance testing (UAT) should be planned.
  1. Governance, Compliance & Change Management
  • Compliance Framework Mapping:
    • Align GRC controls with internal policies and external regulations (e.g., SOX, GDPR).
  • Project Planning:
    • Define scope, timeline, budget, and stakeholders.
    • Assign responsibilities across IT, audit, and compliance teams.
  • Training & Enablement:
    • Prepare training materials for end users and administrators.
    • Conduct workshops and simulations.
  • Documentation:
    • Maintain detailed records of configurations, decisions, and test results.

 Summary Checklist

Area

Key Tasks

System Compatibility

S/4HANA version, NetWeaver, HANA DB, OS

Infrastructure

Hardware sizing, OS certification

Licensing & Roles

Module licenses, role definitions, SoD setup

Integration & Connectivity

RFC setup, connector configuration, system landscape

Installation & Config

Media download, workflow setup, business function activation

Data Migration & Upgrade

Legacy data validation, transport management, testing strategy

Governance & Planning

Compliance mapping, training, documentation, stakeholder alignment

Deploying SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is more than a technical upgrade it's a strategic investment in governance, compliance, and risk resilience. By aligning infrastructure, licensing, integration, and organizational readiness from the outset, you set the stage for a smooth implementation and long-term success. A well-prepared checklist not only accelerates deployment but also ensures your GRC framework is scalable, secure, and audit-ready.

Whether you're planning a fresh rollout or upgrading from GRC 12.0, early preparation is key. Let your checklist be your blueprint and your governance goals be your guide.

entry.title: Re: Income Tax Depreciation in India
entry.content:
When you add a new depreciation area to an existing chart of depreciation, SAP doesn‚Äôt automatically populate values (acquisition, accumulated dep, etc.) in that area for existing assets.

As a result:

-During subsequent transactions (like retirement, transfer, or posting of depreciation), SAP tries to derive and adjust area values retroactively.
-This leads to duplicate postings (often ‚ÄúRetirement without revenue‚Äù appearing twice) because SAP attempts to catch up missing values in the new area and replicate existing area postings.

 

SectionDetails
Module / ComponentSAP S/4HANA Finance ‚Üí Asset Accounting (FI-AA)
Business ScenarioCreated new depreciation area 15 for Income Tax Depreciation. For newly created assets, postings are fine. But for existing assets, when updating the depreciation key and performing retirement, system posts duplicate ‚ÄúRetirement without Revenue‚Äù entries in AW01N.
Issue ObservedTwo identical postings for retirement without revenue appear in AW01N with same amounts. GL and AA balances differ.
Root Cause1Ô∏è‚É£ New depreciation area 15 was added after existing assets were created, but its values (APC, accumulated depreciation, etc.) were not initialized.2Ô∏è‚É£ In Customizing (OADB), reference depreciation area not assigned or incorrectly configured.3Ô∏è‚É£ System tried to derive values dynamically during transaction posting, creating double postings.4Ô∏è‚É£ Program AFBN (Initialize Depreciation Area) was not executed after area creation.5Ô∏è‚É£ Area 15 possibly set to ‚ÄúPost to GL‚Äù unnecessarily, causing additional accounting entries.
Impact- Duplicate postings in FI-AA (double retirement lines)- Reconciliation mismatch between GL and AA- Incorrect accumulated depreciation values in area 15- Confusion in financial reporting and audit trail
Configuration / Customizing to CheckT-Code / Path:- OADB ‚Äì Define Depreciation Areas ‚Üí Verify area 15 setup- Ensure Reference Area = 01 (book depreciation area)- ‚ÄúPosting to GL‚Äù unchecked for Income Tax area (if not required)- Chart of Depreciation assigned correctly to company code (OXK3)- Verify Depreciation Key setup (AFAMA)
Resolution Steps1Ô∏è‚É£ Check and Correct Area Setup in OADB:‚Ä¢ Reference area = 01‚Ä¢ No real-time posting if not required.2Ô∏è‚É£ Run Program AFBN (Initialize Depreciation Area):‚Ä¢ Enter Company Code and Area = 15‚Ä¢ Test Run ‚Üí then Update Run‚Ä¢ System copies values from area 01 to 15 for existing assets.3Ô∏è‚É£ Verify Asset Master Data (AS03):‚Ä¢ Ensure area 15 shows populated APC and depreciation values.4Ô∏è‚É£ Reverse Wrong Entries (AB08):‚Ä¢ Reverse double postings from earlier retirements.5Ô∏è‚É£ Repost Retirement (ABAVN / ABAO):‚Ä¢ Now system should post single ‚ÄúRetirement without revenue‚Äù entry.6Ô∏è‚É£ Run Depreciation Recalculation (AFAR):‚Ä¢ Optional but ensures all planned depreciation values are recalculated.7Ô∏è‚É£ Reconcile GL & AA (ABST2 / FAAL):‚Ä¢ Confirm zero balance difference.
Key Programs & Transactions- OADB ‚Üí Define Depreciation Areas- AFBN ‚Üí Initialize Depreciation Area for existing assets- AS03 ‚Üí Display Asset Master Data- AB08 ‚Üí Reverse Asset Document- ABAVN / ABAO ‚Üí Retirement without Revenue- AFAR ‚Üí Recalculate Depreciation- ABST2 / FAAL ‚Üí Reconcile AA vs GL
Example ‚Äì AFBN Execution ParametersCompany Code = 1000Depreciation Area = 15Reference Area = 01Chart of Depreciation = ZCORPTest Run = Yes (first)Update Run = Yes (after verification)Expected Log Message: ‚ÄúDepreciation area 15 initialized for existing assets ‚Äì values copied from area 01.‚Äù
Validation After Fix- AW01N ‚Üí Single retirement posting appears- AS03 ‚Üí Area 15 values populated- AFAR ‚Üí Planned depreciation aligned- ABST2 / FAAL ‚Üí No reconciliation differences- FAGLL03 / FS10N ‚Üí GL balances match AA values
SAP Notes / References- 199169 ‚Äì AFBN: Initialize depreciation areas- 2177954 ‚Äì Duplicate postings after adding new dep area- 188456 ‚Äì How to initialize depreciation area- 307000 ‚Äì AFAR/AFBN consistency programs guidance
Preventive Measures‚úÖ Always execute AFBN immediately after creating a new depreciation area before performing any transaction.‚úÖ Never enable ‚ÄúPost to GL‚Äù for non-ledger areas like Income Tax unless required.‚úÖ Test configuration in a sandbox or QA system first.‚úÖ Verify data consistency in AW01N after every major config change.‚úÖ Document all area changes for audit trail.
Expected Final OutcomeAfter AFBN execution and reposting:‚Ä¢ No duplicate lines in AW01N‚Ä¢ Correct retirement postings‚Ä¢ Fully reconciled AA and GL balances‚Ä¢ Stable depreciation processing across all areas (01 and 15)

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: F0718 (Post General Journal Entries) with locked docu...
entry.content:
Hi @djwafelap ,

Below is a complete one-table summary explaining functional behavior, limitations, and all available configuration/authorization approaches.

 

SectionDetails / Explanation
Business requirement‚Ä¢ Users with Role A ‚Üí may change document type.‚Ä¢ Users with Role B ‚Üí must use pre-set document type, cannot change it.
App concernedF0718 ‚Äì Post General Journal Entries (Fiori ID: F0718).
Default behaviour‚Ä¢ The app reads defaults from a template or posting variant.‚Ä¢ The ‚ÄúRead Only‚Äù checkbox for document type in templates is greyed out by design ‚Üí cannot be activated manually.
Why ‚ÄúRead Only‚Äù cannot be ticked‚Ä¢ In SAP standard Fiori design for F0718 templates, only certain header fields (e.g., Company Code, Posting Date) can be locked; document type is excluded because the system must allow override when copying templates.‚Ä¢ This is a hard-coded UI restriction (SAP Note / KBA 3246069 and 3154605 mention similar template-field limits).
Direct workaround inside template‚ùå Not possible ‚Äî ‚ÄúRead Only‚Äù flag is disabled by design and not extensible by in-app key user tools.
Alternative 1 ‚Äì Authorization-based control (recommended)Use authorization object F_BKPF_BL ‚Üí controls permitted document types per user/role.Steps:1. In Maintain Business Roles (App ID ‚ÄúMaintain Business Roles‚Äù), find the technical catalog item for F0718.2. Under Business Catalog ‚Üí Authorization Objects, maintain object F_BKPF_BL.3. For Role A, leave DOC Type (*) = all allowed.4. For Role B, restrict DOC Type = specific type(s) (e.g., SA or Z1).‚úÖ Effect: user can post only permitted document type; if they try to change, system error ‚ÄúDocument type not permitted (F5 165)‚Äù appears.
Alternative 2 ‚Äì App variant with UI adaptationFor public-cloud tenants where custom authorizations can‚Äôt be fine-tuned:‚Ä¢ Use Adapt UI ‚Üí Create App Variant for F0718.‚Ä¢ Pre-set document type (Z1) in the UI layout.‚Ä¢ Hide the Document Type field (set Visible = False).‚Ä¢ Publish variant to the catalog used by Role B only.‚úÖ Effect: field invisible/unchangeable for those users; Role A keeps original app.
Alternative 3 ‚Äì Business Role separationCreate two business roles / catalogs:‚Ä¢ Role A = standard F0718.‚Ä¢ Role B = app variant (locked doc type).Assign respective variant/catalog via Maintain Business Roles app.
Alternative 4 ‚Äì Validation or BAdI‚Ä¢ In Private Cloud / on-premise, use validation (OB28) or BAdI BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT to check document type vs user ID and raise error.‚Ä¢ In Public Cloud, limited BAdIs: BAdI FIN_JOURNAL_ENTRY_POST can validate header fields before posting and reject if document type ‚â† allowed.
Suggested combination (Public Cloud)‚Üí Use UI variant to hide/lock field for restricted role + authorization F_BKPF_BL to enforce at posting level.
Testing steps1Ô∏è‚É£ Login as Role A ‚Üí F0718 app ‚Üí document type editable.2Ô∏è‚É£ Login as Role B ‚Üí F0718 app variant ‚Üí field hidden/greyed.3Ô∏è‚É£ Try posting with different type ‚Üí system rejects if unauthorized.
SAP Notes / References‚Ä¢ 3154605 ‚Äì Journal Entry Templates ‚Äì fields cannot be locked.‚Ä¢ 3246069 ‚Äì F0718 field control limitations.‚Ä¢ KBA 2822493 ‚Äì F_BKPF_BL authorization usage for document types.‚Ä¢ SAP Help: Manage Journal Entries (F0718) ‚Üí Authorizations.
Final Recommendation‚úÖ Public Cloud: Use App Variant + Authorization restriction.‚úÖ Private Cloud: Optionally add Validation / BAdI for extra enforcement.‚úÖ Document type locking via template alone = not supported.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: DRC - Run Statutory Report - Add next run for the rep...
entry.content:
Hi @G_hind01 ,

You cannot manually ‚ÄúAdd Next Run‚Äù for non‚ÄìAd Hoc statutory reports in DRC.
The next run is generated automatically according to the report‚Äôs configured frequency and period logic.
To prepare early or simulate, you can only:

-Use an Ad Hoc variant
-Adjust the reporting period parameters in configuration / job scheduling.

SectionDetails / Explanation
AppRun Statutory Reports (DRC)
Your scenarioYou have successfully run local statutory reports (e.g., VAT, SAF-T, GST, Intrastat, etc.) for October and now want to prepare November and December runs in advance (non‚Äìad hoc reports).
Observed behavior‚Ä¢ You can click ‚ÄúAdd Next Run‚Äù for Ad Hoc reports only.‚Ä¢ For periodic reports, there is no ‚ÄúAdd Next Run‚Äù button visible.
Reason / Root cause‚Ä¢ For non‚ÄìAd Hoc reports, the runs are generated automatically by the system based on:‚ÄÉ‚Äì Report Definition configuration (reporting frequency: monthly, quarterly, yearly, etc.)‚ÄÉ‚Äì Current reporting period and offset settings.‚Ä¢ Therefore, you cannot manually add future runs ‚Äî they appear only when the next period becomes due according to the configuration.
Where to check frequency definitionApp: Define Statutory Reports (configuration activity ID: 102260 ‚Äì Define Statutory Reports)or via Manage Your Solution ‚Üí Application Area: Financial Accounting ‚Üí Subarea: Statutory Reporting.
Key fields controlling next run- Reporting Frequency (Monthly, Quarterly, Yearly, etc.)- Period Determination Logic (Calendar-based, Fiscal-based)- Earliest Run Date (determines when next period becomes available)- Company Code Assignment (which entities are linked to the report).
How the system generates new run periods‚Ä¢ After you complete (or mark as ‚ÄúReady for Submission‚Äù / ‚ÄúSubmitted‚Äù) a reporting period, the system automatically adds the next period run once the system date crosses into the next reporting period.‚Ä¢ No manual creation possible unless the report is configured as Ad Hoc.
Workaround to prepare next period early1Ô∏è‚É£ Go to Manage Statutory Reports (if available for your country/localization).2Ô∏è‚É£ Adjust the Reporting Period determination date (if permitted) to generate next run earlier.3Ô∏è‚É£ For some local reports, you can duplicate the existing report definition and temporarily set it to Ad Hoc = Yes to test upcoming period logic (then revert to standard).
Alternative in certain localizationsSome local content (e.g., Spain SII, India GST, Poland SAF-T) allows creation of future runs manually via ‚ÄúGenerate Run‚Äù button in Manage Statutory Reports.However, this button appears only when report definition supports Manual Run Creation = Yes.
If you need to schedule future periods systematicallyUse Schedule Statutory Report Generation (Job Template) in Schedule Application Jobs app ‚Äî available for some local reports. The job automatically creates the next runs once due dates arrive.
Typical behavior by report type 
Ad Hoc ReportsUser can manually click ‚ÄúAdd Next Run‚Äù anytime.
Periodic Reports (Monthly/Quarterly)Next run created automatically once current period ends or system date ‚â• start of next period.
Automated Job-Controlled ReportsManaged through scheduled job templates; user cannot manually create runs.
SAP Reference Notes / Docs- SAP Help Portal ‚Üí Document and Reporting Compliance, Run Statutory Reports ‚Äì Creating and Managing Runs.- SAP Note 3241995 ‚Äì ‚ÄúRun Statutory Reports: Period generation logic‚Äù.- SAP KBA 3334919 ‚Äì ‚ÄúNext run not visible for non-Ad Hoc statutory reports‚Äù.
Recommended approach (best practice)‚úÖ Ensure report definition frequency and ‚ÄúEarliest Run Date‚Äù are correct.‚úÖ Let system generate November/December runs automatically when period becomes active.‚úÖ For testing upcoming periods, use Ad Hoc copy of the report.
Expected outcome‚Ä¢ Non-Ad Hoc (monthly) reports automatically show new run for November once October run is completed and system date ‚â• November 1.‚Ä¢ December run appears when November period is open.


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Query on Accounting Principle Config
entry.content:
Hi @SaiSC2 ,

To replicate postings from a source using Local GAAP & Local Currency as Group Currency into a CFIN target using US GAAP & USD as Group Currency:
üîπ Use Accounting Principle Mapping and Currency Mapping in CFIN.
üîπ System automatically converts currencies and aligns ledgers.
üîπ For structural GAAP differences, use separate ledger or BAdI adjustments.

 

AreaDetails / Explanation
Scenario‚Ä¢ Source system: Local GAAP (e.g., IFRS/Local) and local currency = Group Currency (e.g., EUR).‚Ä¢ Target system (CFIN): US GAAP and Group Currency = USD.‚Ä¢ You need to replicate postings from source ‚Üí CFIN target system, even though accounting principles & group currencies differ.
Key challengeüîπ Source and Target have different accounting principles (e.g., Local GAAP vs. USGAAP).üîπ Source and Target have different group currencies.‚û°Ô∏è Direct replication of journal entries may lead to currency inconsistencies or incorrect valuation logic in target system.
ObjectiveTo correctly bring source postings into CFIN (for US GAAP) while preserving accurate values, and allowing adjustments for different accounting principles.
Recommended approachUse Central Finance (CFIN) with Accounting Principle Mapping + Currency Translation logic enabled.
Key Components Involved1Ô∏è‚É£ SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server) for real-time replication.2Ô∏è‚É£ Central Finance Mapping Framework (FI Mapping, Accounting Principle Mapping, Company Code Mapping, Currency Mapping).3Ô∏è‚É£ Source‚ÄìTarget Accounting Principle Mapping (via Financial Accounting Principle in CFIN customizing).4Ô∏è‚É£ Central Posting Logic (BADI Implementations)* to derive correct target GAAP values if needed.
Configuration StepsSteps
  
1. Define Accounting PrinciplesIn CFIN target: SPRO ‚Üí Financial Accounting (New) ‚Üí Financial Accounting Global Settings ‚Üí Ledgers ‚Üí Accounting Principle ‚Üí Define Accounting Principles.
2. Assign Ledgers to Accounting PrinciplesAssign separate ledgers to different GAAPs, e.g.,‚Ä¢ Ledger 0L ‚Üí US GAAP (Leading Ledger)‚Ä¢ Ledger 2L ‚Üí Local GAAP (if needed for reconciliation).
3. Map Source to Target Accounting PrincipleIn CFIN customizing ‚Üí Cross-System Mapping ‚Üí Mapping for Accounting ‚Üí Accounting Principle Mapping.Here, map the source GAAP (e.g., IFRS) to target GAAP (USGAAP).
4. Define Currency MappingEnsure Currency Mapping exists in CFIN (Cross-System Mapping ‚Üí Currency Mapping).This maps EUR (source) ‚Üí USD (target group currency).
5. Maintain Exchange Rate Type LogicAssign correct Exchange Rate Type (e.g., M or G) to convert source local currency to target group currency (USD) during replication.Configure via SPRO ‚Üí CFIN ‚Üí Accounting Integration ‚Üí Define Exchange Rate Type for Replication.
6. Enable Document Splitting and Ledger-Specific PostingsEnsure correct ledger assignment and document splitting rules are consistent with US GAAP requirements.
7. Replication via SLTSLT sends FI/CO postings ‚Üí CFIN staging tables ‚Üí AIF (Application Interface Framework).During posting, mapping and conversion logic is applied automatically.
8. BAdI Enhancements (if required)Implement BAdIs like:‚Ä¢ CFIN_AC_INTERFACE_MODIFY ‚Äì to adjust accounting principle/currency during replication.‚Ä¢ CFIN_CUST_EXCHRATE_DET ‚Äì to control exchange rate derivation for target system.
9. Reporting and ValidationValidate posting correctness via:‚Ä¢ Transaction code FINS_CFIN_DFV_MONITOR (Data consistency).‚Ä¢ FINS_CFIN_MAP_MANAGE (Mapping overview).‚Ä¢ FINS_CFIN_AIF (Error handling).
Alternative Design OptionIf US GAAP adjustments are significantly different, create separate ledger in CFIN for Local GAAP replication (mirror of source postings) and derive US GAAP via Adjustments / Central Manual Entries (preferred in consolidation environments).
Key Consideration ‚Äì Group Currency- In source: Group Currency = Local Currency (e.g., EUR).- In CFIN: Group Currency = USD.‚úÖ During replication, the system automatically performs currency conversion using the exchange rate maintained in target (OB08).‚úÖ No manual re-entry required.
Restrictions / Caveats- You cannot post directly to multiple accounting principles in a single replication step.- If Local GAAP ‚Üí US GAAP adjustments involve structural differences (e.g., capitalization rules), those must be handled as adjustment entries in CFIN.- Always ensure exchange rate consistency between systems to avoid rounding errors.
Validation Tools- CFIN_MONITOR ‚Üí to check replicated documents.- AIF Monitor ‚Üí to identify failed mappings or currency mismatches.- Consistency Check Reports (FINS_CFIN_CC).
SAP Reference Notes- SAP Note 2500202 ‚Äì Currency conversion in CFIN.- SAP Note 2346233 ‚Äì Mapping framework usage.- SAP Note 2774481 ‚Äì Accounting principle mapping and replication.- SAP Note 2570014 ‚Äì CFIN replication with different ledgers/currencies.
Recommended Best Practice‚úÖ Map source accounting principle to US GAAP ledger in target.‚úÖ Enable automatic currency conversion via CFIN currency mapping.‚úÖ Use BAdIs to fine-tune any valuation/currency rules.‚úÖ If differences are large, maintain secondary ledger for Local GAAP tracking in CFIN.
Expected Outcome- Source postings replicate into CFIN correctly, converted into USD for group reporting under US GAAP.- System applies mapping and currency conversion automatically.- Audit trail maintained via AIF logs and mapping framework.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: CVI Conversion issue
entry.content:
Hi @Shekhard ,

FD32 ‚Üí UKM000 data replication does not happen automatically during CVI.
You must migrate classic credit data using programs like UKM_TRANSFER_DATA or UKM_MIGRATION_CREDIT_MASTER_DATA after activating FSCM Credit Management.
Once done, the BP UKM000 role will reflect the migrated credit limits and segments.

 

SectionDetails / Explanation
System Context- SAP S/4HANA or S/4HANA Conversion Project (ECC ‚Üí S/4HANA).- You have completed CVI configuration and CVI_COCKPIT processing.- Business Partner (BP) is created for customers, but UKM000 role is missing / not populated with FD32 data.
Root Cause1Ô∏è‚É£ Classic credit management (transaction FD32) uses Credit Control Area (KNKK table).2Ô∏è‚É£ In S/4HANA, Credit Management is part of SAP Credit Management (FIN-FSCM-CR) and stores data in UKMBP_CMS / UKMBP_CMS_SGM tables.3Ô∏è‚É£ The conversion does not automatically migrate FD32 ‚Üí UKM000 unless FSCM Credit Management is active and migration steps are executed.
Key UnderstandingFD32 data = Classic Credit Management (FI-AR-CR).UKM000 role = New Credit Management (FSCM).‚û°Ô∏è The system treats them as different architectures. Simple CVI does not transfer FD32 data into UKM tables automatically.
ObjectiveTo migrate FD32 (classic credit data) into Business Partner UKM000 (FSCM Credit Management) role data, so that converted BPs show corresponding credit master data in BP ‚Üí UKM000 tab.
High-Level Solution FlowClassic FD32 Data (KNKK) ‚Üí Migration Program (UKM_TRANSFER / UKM_MIGRATION) ‚Üí BP Role UKM000 / UKMBP_CMS Tables.
Detailed Step-by-Step Solution 
Step 1 ‚Äì Activate FSCM Credit Management- Ensure FIN-FSCM-CR business function is active.- Transaction: SFW5 ‚Üí Activate FIN_FSCM_CCD and FIN_FSCM_CCD_INTEGRATION.- Confirm configuration via node: SPRO ‚Üí Financial Supply Chain Management ‚Üí Credit Management ‚Üí Integration with AR/AP.
Step 2 ‚Äì Check BP Role Assignment- Verify that BP role UKM000 (Credit Management) exists and is assigned to the correct BP grouping.- Transaction: BP ‚Üí Change mode ‚Üí add role UKM000 if not auto-assigned.
Step 3 ‚Äì Migrate FD32 Data to FSCM- Run migration program: UKM_TRANSFER_CUSTOMIZING (to transfer Credit Control Area customizing).- Then execute program: UKM_TRANSFER_DATA (or UKM_MIGRATION_CREDIT_MASTER_DATA) to transfer customer credit master data from KNKK (FD32) ‚Üí UKM tables.- You can also use transaction UKM_MIGRATION (wizard for both customizing and data).
Step 4 ‚Äì Verify Mapping of Company Code & Credit Control Area- In S/4HANA, Credit Segment = Company Code (normally).- During migration, ensure credit control area (KNA1-KKBER) correctly maps to credit segment (UKM_SGMNT).- If 1:1 mapping not set, maintain in customizing: SPRO ‚Üí FSCM ‚Üí Credit Management ‚Üí Integration with AR/AP ‚Üí Define Relationship Between Company Code and Credit Segment.
Step 5 ‚Äì Execute Migration ReportProgram: UKM_MIGRATION_CREDIT_MASTER_DATAParameters:‚Ä¢ Company code‚Ä¢ Credit control area‚Ä¢ Customer range‚Ä¢ Test run (first execute in simulation).‚û°Ô∏è This program reads data from KNKK (FD32) and updates UKMBP_CMS/UKMBP_CMS_SGM.‚û°Ô∏è Automatically creates BP role UKM000 if BP exists.
Step 6 ‚Äì Check BP After Migration- Transaction: BP ‚Üí Open the Business Partner.- Switch to Role: UKM000 (Credit Management).- Verify Credit Segment Data tab shows migrated credit limits, risk category, currency, etc.
Step 7 ‚Äì Validate via Tables / Reports- Table UKMBP_CMS ‚Üí BP header credit data.- Table UKMBP_CMS_SGM ‚Üí BP segment data (limit, currency, risk class).- Compare with KNKK (classic).
Step 8 ‚Äì Reconcile & Activate- Run consistency check report: UKM_CHECK_CREDIT_ACCOUNT.- If needed, assign Credit Segment BP via UKM_BP_CMS_ASSIGN.
Step 9 ‚Äì Optional Enhancements- If special mapping logic is needed (e.g., multiple credit control areas), enhance BAdI UKM_CREDIT_ACCOUNT_ASSIGNMENT to control how migration maps credit accounts to segments.
Key Transactions- FD32 ‚Üí Classic credit master.- UKM_BP ‚Üí BP Credit Management (UKM000 role).- UKM_TRANSFER_DATA / UKM_MIGRATION ‚Üí Data migration.- UKM_CHECK_CREDIT_ACCOUNT ‚Üí Validation.- BP ‚Üí Business Partner maintenance.
Post-Migration Testing‚úÖ Create a sales order ‚Üí system should pick credit data from BP UKM000.‚úÖ Run report FDM_COLL_SEND_CUSTOMER if credit data should flow to collections management.
  
Common IssuesIssue
  
UKM000 role missingAdd manually or re-run UKM_MIGRATION with correct BP mapping.
Credit limit not transferredCheck credit segment mapping (Company Code ‚Üî Credit Control Area).
Risk class missingVerify customizing transfer via UKM_TRANSFER_CUSTOMIZING.
Multiple Credit Control Areas in sourceHandle via manual assignment or enhancement BAdI.
FD32 data not visible after migrationEnsure FIN-FSCM-CR active and UKM_BP roles generated correctly.
SAP Notes & References- SAP Note 2691534 ‚Äì Migration of Credit Management Data to UKM_BP.- SAP Note 2603674 ‚Äì UKM_MIGRATION report usage.- SAP Note 2777273 ‚Äì Credit Segment mapping guidance.- SAP Help: CVI Conversion with FSCM Credit Management Migration.
Expected Outcome‚úÖ FD32 (Classic Credit Management) data migrated into UKM tables.‚úÖ BP role UKM000 automatically updated/created.‚úÖ Credit limits, risk class, control area appear correctly under BP ‚Üí UKM000 tab.‚úÖ Sales and AR processes use new Credit Management logic.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Mastering the Data Deluge: A Comprehensive Guide to SAP Data Strategy and Archiving
entry.content:
Thanks for this very useful blog.

You mention YAC which is indeed an SAP add-on (pure ABAP, no middleware needed) that facilitates the integration of attachments and documents from SAP ERP and S/4HANA systems (also RISE) with various Document Management Systems (DMS) both in the cloud and on-premises.

These last years it's mainly the YAC for SharePoint version that has been used by many customers to store SAP attachments in automatically generated folders with intelligent attributes, in SharePoint / Teams / OneDrive / AzureBlob.

Note that there is also a similar solution named SA2S working for all SaaS business solutions such as SuccessFactors
SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), Oracle Fusion Cloud, Workday, NetSuite (Oracle) and even SAP S/4HANA Cloud !

entry.title: Re: No payment media were created because of manual appro...
entry.content:
Hello Samuel,

I hope you are doing well.

Please see the SAP KBA below:

3672167 - Payment Program Error: "No payment media were created because of manual approval needed."https://me.sap.com/notes/3672167/E

  • Using Manage Bank Account app; In the Payment Approver tab/section of the relevant House Bank Account, ensure there are no approvers defined, especially if the customer intends for payments to be auto-approved or only approved via a separate flexible workflow.
  • If a workflow is intentionally active (Scope Item J78/J77), the next action is for the designated user to approve the payment batch in the Approve Bank Payments Fiori app. Once approved, the payment media generation will complete.
  • If no flexible workflow is set up, the check on the Manage Bank Accounts app is critical to ensure no unintended approvals are required at the bank master data level.

Best Regards

Fabio

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Question about Higher-Level Item Linking in Service O...
entry.content:
Hello  @YBS ,

thanks for raising your question!

In Service Order we only support two-level hierarchy based on the functionality Service Bundle. Moreover, the main-item must be of type "Service Bundle" (fixed-price Service Bundle or Service Bundle). Based on that the item category determination is defined. This is also the reason why your item category is blank. Please take a closer look at the following SAP Help.

Best regards,
Julius - SAP Cloud ERP Consulting

entry.title: Re: BZSTDOC
entry.content:
Hi  cmfs5

For this issue, I kindly ask you to please check and apply the following SAP Notes:

1873607 - Optimized Log Configuration and Database Size for Integration Framework

1873559 - B1iF_Using the DB Purge Tool for Database Size Reduction

And also, I kindly ask you to double  check below mentioned article to control the Integration Framework logs https://help.sap.com/doc/9c200d7b20af4b5f9f29bafdb2401579/9.0/en-US/B1if%20Log%20Maintenance.pdf

1. Make sure that the B1i debug settings are set as a Production environment, as detailed in SAP Note 1873607, section "6. Best practice: Log configuration for production servers".

2. Use the B1i ‚Üí Tools ‚Üí Log Mass Deletion, to delete unnecessary logging information and maintain the size of the B1i database.

3. Perform the steps below to release any unused or fragmented space (see KBA 3107274, section A.8):

    3.1. Schedule some downtime on the HANA Server, making sure there are no connected users

    3.2. Stop the server tools, B1i and any other services that connect to the HANA instance

    3.3. Perform a Full Backup of the instance

    3.4. Restart the HANA Instance

    3.5. Execute the following SQL statements in HANA Studio:

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM DATAVOLUME 120 DEFRAGMENT;

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM LOG;

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM COLUMN LOB SPACE;

        ALTER SYSTEM RECLAIM ROW LOB SPACE;

    3.6. Start the Server tools and other services again.

Check if BZSTDOC table size is reduced after this.

Thank You.

Kimd Regards
Nidhi
SAP Support

entry.title: Leave accrual based on working days i previous year
entry.content:
Hi @Volker_Ruof / @StephanieCR  / experts / product owners,

We are busy exploring a configuration scenario where the annual leave entitlement is determined by the number of working days in the previous year.

A working day is defined as:

  • A normal working day

  • Working on a non-working day

  • More than 4 hours of overtime booked in a day

  • Absence due to a work accident, strike, etc.
    (There are a few other basic conditions, but these are the main ones.)

The working day checks have been achieved using time valuations, which add to a counter in a time collector. This correctly calculates the number of working days.

The accrual period and account validity are based on the employee‚Äôs hire date. For example, the number of working days from 1 June 2024 to 31 May 2025 determines the entitlement for 1 June 2025.

This would have been straightforward if all employees shared the same accrual period, as we could use a flexible-period time collector. However, because the period differs per employee (based on hire date), this becomes more complex.

We are currently considering two possible approaches and would appreciate your feedback or alternative suggestions:

Scenario 1:
Leverage a workaround within the decision or calculation rule (details can be shared privately with product owners or experts) to manipulate or assign values to the time valuation/time type group, thereby determining working days for the relevant annual period.

Scenario 2:
Use a daily time collector that writes to a custom object. The accrual rule would then read the value from this custom object, populated via an onSave rule in the timesheet or time type groups.
The downside is potential performance issues, and it would not automatically capture retrospective timesheet changes unless the timesheet is re-saved.

Would love to hear your thoughts, feedback or alternative approaches.

Thank you!

 

SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking

entry.title: Double GR Posting- Locking Issue
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am facing this issue recently, we have the control key as PP02(Auto GR), While completing the last operation in DM   yield is posted and then goods receipt is automatically posted. So when order Qty is 2, GR  Qty is 2 obviously.

But in some situations while DM posting the last operation locking issue occurs, causing the posting to occur in COGI. When we reprocess the COGI entry, another 101 movement is also triggered.

As a result, Order Qty is 2, GR posting is 4 -> 2Qty (MB31-AutoGR) and Second GR - 2QTY COGI.

Pls suggest me configuration changes which can be made to stop this issue.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series ‚Äì Colors, Creativity, and Canvases ‚Äì Sandra Sol√≠s
entry.content:
Just like smarchesini enjoys discovering and connecting with places through
running, I also love to connect with the places I visit ‚Äî but through painting. I‚Äôm
excited to continue the SAP Community Hobbies series by sharing another passion
that takes me away from the keyboard yet still connects back in surprising ways:
drawing and painting.

A Little About Me and My Hobby

Hello everyone! My name is Sandra Sol√≠s, I‚Äôm an ABAP developer from Mexico and also the creator of the YouTube channel Mundo Abaper, where I share ABAP content in Spanish. Like Sebastiano, I enjoy running, making ABAP content of course, but the hobby that truly wins my heart is drawing and painting.

Over the years, I‚Äôve explored many techniques‚Äîcolored pencils, charcoal, watercolor, acrylics, and even coffee painting. For me, every medium has its own charm and challenge.

How It All Started

My journey with art began when I was 15 years old, in secondary school, when I took an art class, and that‚Äôs when I started practicing this hobby. What started as curiosity became a lifelong practice‚Äî20 years now! Since then, my sketchbooks, canvases, and brushes have been my constant companions.

What I Love Most

When I paint, the world slows down. It‚Äôs just me and the canvas. This hobby gives me a moment of peace but also sparks unexpected creativity for my programming work. Many times, while drawing, a solution to an ABAP problem suddenly comes to my mind.

Connecting Art with SAP

At first glance, painting may seem far from the SAP world. But here‚Äôs where I find the link:

Visual thinking: Sketching helps me structure ideas, the same way I design solutions. It also helps me take notes with small drawings, which makes it easier to understand what I study and read.

  • Creative problem-solving: When I feel overwhelmed or can‚Äôt find a solution, I step away and start painting. Suddenly, while I‚Äôm painting, some answers appear, helping me get unstuck and find solutions.
  • Content creation: For my Mundo Abaper videos, I often use drawings and visual notes to explain concepts more clearly.

So while brushes and SAP might seem unrelated, creativity is the bridge between them.

Challenges Along the Way

Art is not always easy. Portraits, for example, are especially challenging‚Äîcapturing the essence of a face requires patience and practice. Learning each new technique (like watercolor vs. charcoal) also brings its own learning curve. I‚Äôve overcome these challenges through courses and, most importantly, constant practice.

Proud Moments

Some highlights of my artistic journey:

  • Portraits of the SAP Developer Advocates‚Äîpainted with coffee!

 

  • My travel journal, a tiny handmade sketchbook filled with paintings of the beautiful places I‚Äôve visited, here I show just a few ones on my sketchbook . 

    

    

  • A charcoal portrait of Madona

  • My favorite superhero in colored pencils.

  • And one special project: a handmade badge painted with acrylics that I use as a background for my videos.

I even have a iman that I use as watercolor pallet of Paint !!! perfect match between computers and painting, dont you think??

 

Myths About Painting

Many people believe painting or drawing is only for those ‚Äúborn with talent.‚Äù I strongly disagree. With a good mentor and consistent practice, anyone can improve‚Äîyes, even to the level of Van Gogh!

Tips for Beginners

  • Start with the fundamentals, no matter which painting technique you choose, they all share the same, learn lines, dots, perspective, volume, shadows, light, and composition.
  • Once you‚Äôre comfortable, choose a technique you like‚Äîwatercolor, pencils, charcoal‚Äîand deepen your skills there.

Where to Learn More

There are countless resources, both free and paid. My personal recommendation: start with YouTube tutorials to get the basics, then take structured courses to refine your technique.

As you can see, art, is more than a hobby‚Äîit‚Äôs a way to recharge, connect with us, and even find inspiration for our SAP work. I‚Äôd love to hear from you too: What hobby fuels your creativity outside of SAP?

Passing the Baton

Next, I‚Äôd like to forward to Riney Riley, who will share an exciting hobby of skydiving

entry.title: Automating SAP Business One Sales Reporting with n8n, AI, and Telegram
entry.content:
Introduction

This workflow integrates SAP Business One data through the Service Layer with Google Sheets and Telegram. The purpose of this workflow is to automate sales reporting process by automatically retrieving new sales orders, updating google sheets with new orders, and delivering daily summaries via Telegram. Google‚Äôs Gemma AI used in this workflow to add extra insights and analyze the consolidated data in order to highlighting top performers, upcoming due dates, and extracting sales trends by removing manual data exports and providing real-time visibility of sales performance.

 

Technical Architecture

The workflow includes two main stages. First, it connects to the Service Layer to retrieve sales orders data with the help of OData queries, filters out duplicates orders, and appends new orders to Google Sheets. Second, it uses JavaScript code to format the data, create structured AI prompts, and deliver the finalized reports through a Telegram Bot. (The social platfrom can be vary based on the user requirements.)

Prerequisites

  • SAP Business One Access: A valid database with authorized username, password, and active Service Layer. (SBODemoUS data used in this tutorial)
  • Docker: Docker Desktop used to deploy n8n.
  • Google Account: Google Sheets and Google API setup.
  • Telegram Account: A Telegram account to create a bot and obtain a user ID for notifications. (this can be applicable to any other platform)
  • n8n Account: n8n account for deploying and configuring workflows.
  • Javascript: JavaScript syntax used to in n8n nodes.

Implementation Steps

The workflow follows these stages:

  1. Deploying n8n on the server
  2. SAP Business One Integration
  3. Validate SAP Business One data
  4. Create automated workflow
  5. Google Sheets Data Synchronization
  6. Sales Analysis in Google Sheets
  7. AI-Powered Sales Insights
  8. Automated Reporting to Telegram

Implementation

The process starts by checking the latest sales orders in SAP Business One:

Next step is to deploy n8n in Docker and set up Service Layer using HTTP nodes for login and data retrieval. Example OData query would be like this:

https://server:50000/b1s/v1/Orders?$select=DocEntry,DocDate,CardName&$orderby=DocEntry desc&$top=10

A JavaScript code node also handles duplicate checking. It can grab existing rows from Google Sheets, pulls out DocEntry values, and filters SAP data to include only new sales orders. This prevent duplication when the workflow runs multiple times.

For having AI analysis, a JavaScript node formats the sales data into a prompt and calculates daily totals, identify top performers, and computes monthly averages. The prompt asks Gemma AI to generate a report with a performance summary, and alerts. Finally, the Telegram node sends the formatted report to specific user id, including the date, total sales, top performers, AI insights, and upcoming due dates.

Final Thoughts

This workflow automates sales order retrieval from SAP Business One through Service Layer and syncs new orders to Google Sheets. By using n8n, it delivers daily reports via Telegram and remove the need for manual data exports. The implementation requirements are SAP Business One Service Layer, Docker, n8n, and JavaScript to perform calculations with AI assistance. Although calculations can be done with just code, AI can help to get extra insights based on the given prompt. Beyond sales reporting, this approach can be applied to other modules such as purchasing, inventory management, or crm and making it a cost-effective alternative to enterprise automation platforms.

 

Resources 

The full guide is available as a PDF with step-by-step instructions and screenshots. The JavaScript code is in GitHub with comments.

  • Full Guide PDF
  • GitHub Repository

 

Prepared by

Amirhossein Tonekaboni
SAP Business One Consultant

  • LinkedIn
  • Portfolio

entry.title: Re: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
entry.content:
@nageshcaparthy - Thanks for a well-documented guide.
I observed one thing, in your guide, when creating the SAP_COM_0193 communication arrangement, it is mentioned to use the S4HANA URL domain as the HOST. 

However in the SAP Mission -

Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it is mentioned to use the IAS tenant (Cloud Identity Service) domain as the HOST. 
 
This was possibly the reason why no user roles were replicated from S4HANA system to SAP Build Workzone and Joule considered everyone as unauthorised users. Due to this, Joule never answered our queries correctly or atleast the answers were very generic and vague.
After I made the changes in the HOST, the IPS was able to extract the user roles from S4HANA cloud system and replicate them to BUILD workzone. With the authorization of the users now available, Joule became more accurate and decisive and was now able to answer queries and also show navigational links based on the queries.
